abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the National Agricultural
            Advisory Services (NAADS) Project for Uganda were as
            follows: outcomes were moderately satisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was moderate, Bank performance was
            moderately satisfactory, and Borrower performance was also
            moderately satisfactory. Lessons learned include: the NAADS
            Project was the first in Africa to incorporate public
            funding and pluralistic provision of services as a national
            program, with farmers empowered to select their service
            providers. Prior to introduction of the NAADS Program,
            questions were raised as to whether such a program shown to
            work elsewhere, particularly in Latin America, will be
            suitable and feasible in Africa. The NAADS experience offers
            many lessons about how best to adapt such a model, but a
            fundamental conclusion can be drawn that the programs are
            suitable and superior to the centralized traditional model
            of public funding and public provision of services. The fact
            that the Government of Uganda (GOU) saw NAADS as a public
            program, rather than an enclave project of the donors, gave
            the program weight and an opportunity to be transformative,
            through scale and mainstreaming into governmental systems.
            Few countries have the equivalent of the NAADS Act to
            safeguard design of programs. This can be a very
            constructive measure when programs require long duration to
            reach impact, but governments and priorities may change
            frequently. Advisory services appear to have had a greater
            impact than subsidized provision of inputs under the
            program. This finding is very provisional and warrants more
            careful investigation, since it is critical to policy
            dialogue in African agriculture at present. Many governments
            are of the view that widespread distribution of subsidized
            fertilizer will achieve rapid gains in productivity and
            incomes. The NAADS experience suggests that the most
            impressive gains were achieved in the period when the
            program concentrated on provision of advice and
            demonstration of technologies. The returns when inputs
            became relatively more important in the program appear to be
            more mixed.
